status.name: Closed

fields.description:
While troubleshooting sessions to figure out why the User Console wasn't working, there were certain messages in the console.log that were very vague.

When we did a git clone of eucayptus-console and modified line 52 in eucaconsole/botoclcinterface.py to "debug=2" we were able to get the following:

{code}
Traceback (most recent call last): 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/eucaconsole/session.py", line 301, in post 
response = LoginProcessor.post(self) 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/eucaconsole/session.py", line 464, in post 
creds = auth.authenticate(account, user, passwd, newpwd) 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/eucaconsole/token.py", line 78, in authenticate 
raise eucaconsole.session.EuiException(504, 'Timed out') 
EuiException
{code}

From the output, it seems to be a communication issue with the CLC (which wasn't the case because the CLC and User Console were on the same machine, and the CLC was running just fine).  On reviewing eucaconsole/token.py it appeared as though lines 77-78 in eucaconsole/token.py were perhaps a little broad in the exception handling. We modified line 78 from this:
{code}
raise eucaconsole.session.EuiException(504, 'Timed out')
{code}

to this:
{code}
raise err
{code}

then retried ./launcher.sh. This time we saw this in the console UI when we tried to login:
{code}
"There was an error with your account/username/password combination. Please try again."
{code}

and stdout from launcher.sh showed this:
{code}
Traceback (most recent call last): 
File "/root/eucalyptus-console/eucaconsole/session.py", line 301, in post 
response = LoginProcessor.post(self) 
File "/root/eucalyptus-console/eucaconsole/session.py", line 464, in post 
creds = auth.authenticate(account, user, passwd, newpwd) 
File "/root/eucalyptus-console/eucaconsole/token.py", line 78, in authenticate 
raise err 
URLError: <urlopen error [Errno 1] _ssl.c:490: error:100AE081:elliptic curve routines:EC_GROUP_new_by_curve_name:unknown group> 
Traceback (most recent call last): 
File "/root/eucalyptus-console/eucaconsole/session.py", line 307, in post 
raise EuiException(401, 'not authorized') 
EuiException
{code}

Research revealed the issue was due to an incorrect version of openssl required by the User Console.  Once we upgraded the openssl package, log in worked correctly.  A couple of things to help here:

* Improve the message from the User Console to mention something more meaningful
* Have pre-req check on either packaging or start up to confirm if the correct openssl version is met for the version of the User Console
fields.summary: Improve message logging for user console regarding the wrong version of openSSL

comments.body:
Judging by the code referenced,  it is 3.4
That said, We have better output in the 4.0 console since we dump the exception details when trying to authenticate. So, an HttpError or UrlError would be sent right to the log to give maximum details, though it might not be user friendly.
relates to the wrong version of openSSL

openssl-1.0.1e-15.el6.x86_64
Judging by http://rpm.pbone.net/index.php3/stat/4/idpl/24668565/dir/scientific_linux_6/com/openssl-1.0.1e-15.el6.x86_64.rpm.html
it has been out a long time. I assume that is what we tested 3.4.x with a few months back. So, it is baffling why this package would be a problem by itself. I think the problem must lay elsewhere and updating to -16 bypassed the problem somehow.

Is this also the one that appears on the centos 6.2 system a customer was using? Maybe doesn't happen for actual centos version we test on?

The 4.0 console should return a 401 Unauthorized response when authentication fails, regardless of OpenSSL version AFAICT.   Need to pin with the OpenSSL version that is known to fail to fully confirm.
The problem was not what do we do when auth fails. It is what do we do when the openssl connection fails due to a library problem. Completely different problem.
[~dkavanagh]: What library are we referring to here?  Boto?

[~kgill]/[~dkavanagh],

The version that failed was here - openssl-1.0.1e-15.  We upgraded to openssl-1.0.1e-16 and it worked like a charm.
[~dkavanagh]: I was asking about the python libraries we use for authentication, not openssl

[~dkavanagh]: What I was getting at with the library question is that openssl isn't the only factor here.  We're using urllib2 to handle the authentication, so it would be great to know if the version of urllib2 is also important.
ok, so have a look at the referenced sup ticket and the stack trace which shows urllib, httplib and ssl code in the stack trace. Hopefully, that will help.
[~hspencer]: Thanks for providing the OpenSSL version!

[~kgill]
I will be adding the version requirement to the spec file. [~gholms] has provided the mechanism. Commit impending.
I think we just give this over to [~viglesias] now.

Yes, 3.4 didn't log much information. It does log a timeout. I'm not sure how the "execution.log" from the support ticket was generated since that doesn't look like a regular python stack trace.
I explicitly added code in 4.0 that dumps the exception to the log so we can get more to go on. We could log a stack trace as well, but that seems like overkill.
The only addition in the 4.0 auth code was dumping the error object to the log. We could add that in 3.4.3 on top of the package dependency fix. [~tjcramer], let me know if that needs to be done.
Confirmed the 4.0 console is properly capturing the appropriate exception in the log when the wrong version of OpenSSL is used.
